title: Ireland’s Rugby World Cup curse continues as New Zealand romp into semi-finals
text:
Rory Best was unable to lead his side into a first ever RWC semi-final (Picture: Getty)

Ireland’s wait for a Rugby World Cup semi-final goes on after they were stuffed 46-14 by New Zealand in a one-sided clash in Tokyo.

Having come through the group stages as runners-up to unbeaten Japan, they met the best side in the world in their first knockout match and suffered their biggest ever World Cup defeat.

Aaron Smith scored twice in the first 20 minutes and it took the Irish more than an hour to get on the scoreboard, with even two late tries doing little to take the edge off a painful loss.

It means Ireland have now lost seven times at the quarter-final stage of the Rugby World Cup, and never gone further.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Andy Farrell’s defence was always likely to be severely tested and at first they held firm as New Zealand took them through the phases inside the 22.

But Smith spotted a hole from seven metres out and sniped to reach out for the first try of the game.

The opportunity was created by All Black persistence but the second try was, to certain extent, self-inflicted.

Sexton failed to find touch from halfway, Mongua brilliantly leaping to claw the ball back into play, and soon after George Bridge swept down the left flank, hauled down short to allow Smith to leap over and score his second of the day.

Smith at the double! Ominous signs here as New Zealand slam in another try Relentless and ruthless#RWC2019 #ITVRugby #NZLvsIRE pic.twitter.com/slbvDbw6VZ — ITV Rugby (@ITVRugby) October 19, 2019

Ireland also had to battle injury as both Garry Ringrose and Robbie Henshaw spent time off the pitch after a clash of heads in midfield but even after they returned, New Zealand were rampant.

A thumping hit on Sexton, who received the now-customary added attention throughout, dragged the ball loose and a fly-hack from Smith was followed by Barrett, who added one of his own to dribble the ball to the line.

Ireland needed a response after half-time when Joe Schmidt resisted the urge to ring the changes, but it was New Zealand who again started better.

With less than 10 minutes gone after the break, Codie Taylor went over from a brilliant off-load by Kieran Read on the ground after yet another spectacular period of ball retention by the All Blacks.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Matt Todd also got on the scoresheet before Robbie Henshaw, after dropping one a minute earlier, ensured the men in green would not suffer a dreaded nil-ing.

New Zealand looked to have the last laugh, Ardie Savea poaching one at the ruck, offloading from six inches off the ground to Dane Coles who in turn passed out of the tackle to Bridge for a well-deserved score.

But Ireland, beaten but unbowed, forced a penalty try when CJ Stander trapped Todd against the base of the post and the All Black was sent to the sin bin as a result.

Even with 14, Jordie Barrett found space to score in the corner and add a little more pain to Ireland’s day.
